text.headline:
Vortex
2005 - 2015
text.text: Vortex is a little story of success. Today, 10 years after it was founded by two doctors of Atmospheric Physics and a self-taught IT expert, the company operates across 3 continents and serves users from 150 countries

media.caption: Pep Moreno, Vortex CEO, installing a met. mast during a measurement campaign in Northern Spain. Early 90’s

text.headline:
A young company
of old experts
text.text: Vortex was established in Barcelona on September 19, 2005 but its team’s track record goes much further back, having accumulated 25 years of experience in the wind industry

media.caption: David Saez, IT Director, at Vortex's computer cluster. Early 2006

text.headline:
It all started with a simple,
powerful idea
text.text: The foundational approach of the Vortex service was simple: remote atmospheric modeling launched on-line. Our first computer cluster was set up in 2006 with the aim to 'bringing the power of a supercomputer to your fingerprints'

media.caption: Professor Josep Calbó, Scientific Advisor, returning from the University of Girona with his two-year old daughter. Late 2006

text.headline: Research in the real world
text.text: We love research. Half of Vortex’s employees hold a PhD and we have close ties with several research institutes since our first collaboration with the University of Girona in 2006. Meanwhile, continuous feedback from our users helps shape our research, making sure we always keep real world 'imperfections' at the forefront of our minds

media.caption: One of the first drafts of the Vortex Interface. Early 2007

text.headline:
Complex modeling,
just one-click away
text.text: From its first design in 2007, the philosophy behind the Vortex Interface was to pare down the complexity of atmospheric modeling to just a few intuitive website user actions. Since the beginning, user manuals and courses were strictly forbidden

media.caption: Pau Casso, Technical Director, at Longs Peak (Colorado) after attending the 9th WRF Users' Workshop in Boulder. July 2008

text.headline: A cloud (service) with solid foundations
text.text: Vortex is not a large company but we are not at all alone. Since our first compilation of the WRF model, Vortex's core technology has relied on a collaborative code developed through the efforts of a community of over 23,000 registered users

media.caption: Gil Lizcano, R&D Director (center), at University of Oxford. Mid 2009

text.headline: Growing slowly but surely
text.text: At the time we closed our first sale in 2009, the original Vortex portfolio included only 3 products. Our current Wind & Site, Forecast, Solar and Offshore portfolios comprise 10 products. Development and testing of new products has been treated with great care by Vortex’s R&D department to ensure service robustness

text.headline: Eruption of the Eyjafjallajökul
text.text: Ashes expelled by this Icelandic volcano on April 2010 affected activities across Europe. There was extensive air travel disruption caused by the closure of airspace... (source: Wikipedia)

media.caption: Receiving the 'Eyjafjallajökul' award from EWEA's COO, Bruce Douglas, during the conference dinner in Warsaw. April 22, 2010

text.headline: Caravan to the East
text.text: EWEC 2010 in Warsaw was going to be our first EWEA annual event as exhibitors but the eruption of the Eyjafjallajökul stopped us from flying. Without thinking twice, we drove up there in a motorhome. Thanks to our 2,400 km trip to Poland, we were given a prize (a bottle of vodka) for being the participants who had driven the furthest to the event!

media.caption: Jordi Ferrer, Managing and Financial Director (bottom), and Pep Moreno at Vortex's partners offices in Beijing. Late 2010

text.headline: 患难识知己<sup>*</sup>
text.text:
Starting in China in 2010, Vortex has expanded into Asia by collaborating with local partners. With offices also in India and Turkey, our partners are now our gateway to the East
* A friend in need is a friend indeed

media.caption: German Delgado, Commercial Director, in Rio de Janeiro. Early 2011

text.headline: Emerging in the Emergents
text.text: Beyond European shores, Brazil, India, China and South Africa, among others, have been Vortex’s priority targets since as early as 2011

media.caption: First Vortex office in Brussels. Late 2011

text.headline: Natural born glocal
text.text: Wind is not limited by borders, and neither is Vortex. By opening our first satellite office in Brussels in 2011, we bolstered our presence in Europe

media.caption: Elies Campmany, at the Vortex computer cluster in Barcelona. Early 2012

text.headline: Run #10,000
text.text: The Vortex computer cluster never sleeps. In the middle of (our) night in 2012, a Korean user launched Run #10,000. Three years on, Run #63,000 was completed last summer

media.caption: Vortex flags erected at EWEA's annual event in Vienna. February 2013

text.headline: At the heart of European wind industry research
text.text: Chairing EWEA's annual event sessions and collaborating with DTU or TPWind, are just a few examples of Vortex's unwavering commitment with European wind industry R&D initiatives

media.caption: Abel Tortosa, Forecast Director (left), at EWEA's Wind Power Forecasting workshop in Rotterdam. December 2013

text.headline: Looking ahead and beyond
text.text: While Wind & Site products refer only to the past, extending Vortex modeling service to the future was a natural step. Vortex’s Forecasting service was launched in 2013 and is not restricted to the short-term but looks beyond through the seasonal-to-decadal climate prediction SPECS project

media.caption: Ed Montero, Manager Director Vortex FdC inc., in Miami. April 2014

text.headline: The land of the free and the home of the brave
text.text: Our presence in the US dates back to AWEA's annual event in Dallas but did not become permanent until we opened a new Vortex office in Florida in April 2014

media.caption: Alex Montornés at the University of Barcelona. Late 2014

text.headline: Citizens of the State-of-the-Art
text.text: In-house R&D is one of the areas in which Vortex invests most resources. Advanced testing of WRF-LES since 2014 is one example. Striving to always be at the cutting-edge of our fields of specialization is the only way a small, agile company can survive

text.headline: Vortex's modest contributions to the Common Good
text.text: During summer 2015, our company joined the ECG movement, an organisation devoted to shifting the economical paradigm to the benefit of the Common Good. Earlier this year, our Director of Happiness received the Innovative Company in Conciliation and Time Prize from Barcelona City Council in recognition of our corporate policy towards the well-being of our own employees

media.caption: Patricia Puig, Vortex Solar (and Happiness) Director. June 2015

text.headline: Here comes the Sun
text.text: June 2015, Intersolar Munich: debut of the Vortex Solar service at the solar sector’s largest trade fair in the world. Our first excursion outside the wind industry but with the same solid foundations and approaches used until now

media.caption: The Vortex team walking along the coast in Empuries, September 2015

text.headline: Next step, the future
text.text: In September 2015 we celebrated Vortex's anniversary in a delightful corner where ancient Greeks first landed on our shores. A meeting to recharge the batteries (using renewable energy of course!) for the next 10 challenging years ahead
